content.description: A fun friction climb that leads to ring anchors (90'). The anchors are shared with two other routes to the right. A good section to bring  the family and do laps!
Climb the somewhat dirty flaring crack to the anchors of 'Axolotl'.
content.location: Located 15' right of 'Axolotl' at a crack.

climbs.name: Slenderman
climbs.fa: Dave Daly, Mark Krebs and Scott Loomis (Aug 2018)

content.description: An excellent climb for the grade, ascending a very unusual feature known as 'the Slenderman! Start by smearing to a slightly out of reach incut. From the generous incut, pull up and clip the first bolt. Make a few delicate balancy moves (crux) before getting to the 2nd bolt. From here, press upward on the rails of the Slenderman silhouette. Clip the 3rd bolt and head up and out of the silhouette to the 4th bolt above. Work out right and up onto fun overhanging knobs to a large knobbed rail, eventually leading to the 5th and final bolt. Climb the remaining section to 2-ring anchors. Lower off.
content.location: This route is located on the far west side, in a mini amphitheater like alcove. Walk west and then north from the parking lot for 5 minutes.

content.description: Start by making bouldery moves up to the first bolt. Step up into large pockets and pull up into the next one. Clip the next bolt and make an awkward and insecure move out left and up (crux). Continue up, passing two more bolts. Chain anchors on top.
content.location: This route is located on the southwest portion of Trout Rock, separate from most of the east facing routes. From the parking area, head directly through the woods to the most southern end of Trout Rock. From a steep wall (abandoned project with two bolts), skirt left and up to a rounded large pocketed prow with red painted bolts. This the start of Sherman's March.

content.description: 'Sherman Tank' initially follows a seam which opens occasionally to pods (1"), along a thin tips crack. Pull your way up on small side pulls, coupled by a few small generous bigger pulls on pods in the crack. An occasional flared finger lock keeps things engaging. Work up to a split and move out right and up along a flared crack. From the sixth bolt, climb out left and continue up toward the anchors above. PUMPY!
content.protection:
- (7) quickdraws

- Slings

- pro: small wires and cams to 1"
content.location: This steep sport climb is the first bolted route on the left, along the east face of Trout Rock. Located 20 feet past a red-tagged project (2 bolts) and signatured by a small seam.

content.description: Another fun slab route, although a bit committing to reach the first bolt. However, the features are all there. Enjoyable friction along with a few knob pulls. Another good "welcome to Trout Rock" moderate!
content.location: 'Hundred Feet Of Feet' is located 15 feet right of 'The Yurt'

content.description: This route uses the same anchor as 'Golden Trout'. Start up a crack then veer off left and up on a balancy seam. Gain patina and join 'Golden Trout'.
Climb the obvious large crack right and up. Can be finished at the anchors of 'Axolotl'. A good beginner lead.
content.location: Start at the same spot as 'Mud Guppy'.

content.description: This is a top rope route that works off of independent anchors. The anchors can be gained by  either scrambling along a terrace or leading up to "Filet Of Sole's anchors. Start off the same section of rock as 'Filet Of Sole'. Pull onto a sloping side pull and smear on subtle bumps to gain a thin sloping hold above. Pull onto this and friction to parallel patina rails. The climbing eases off and heads to crack. Cross over the crack to gain more knobs and patina. Finish at 2-ring anchors. Lower off (70').
content.location: 'Golden Trout' starts at the same location as 'Filet Of Sole, but then works out right and up.

content.description: Start up by reaching up to a subtle rail and pull through, bringing your feet up high. Continue up the right side of the raised rail, clipping 2 bolts along the way. Pass over the second bolt to the left and friction to the third bolt. the climbing eases off from there and continues by passing 3 more bolts to the ring anchor. Lower off 75' or walk off to the left
content.location: Just uphill and past 'Sherman Tank' is the open slab of Trout Rock's east face. 'Mayfly' is located on the far left of the slab, next to a small pine tree.

content.description: Climb up a triangular shaped pedestal to its appex and step out onto the face on good foot holds. Clip the first bolt then step up slightly right on bumps and small dimples. Clip a second bolt and head along a rounded long rail. After the rail, trend left and up, passing one more bolt before joining up with  'Hundred Feet Of Feet' last two bolts before the anchor. Lower off or walk off.
content.location: Start 20' and uphill from 'One Hundred Feet Of Feet. The start is signatured by a triangular shaped pedestal.

content.description:
Start up a fist crack, making a few strenuous moves getting off the ground (#4 Camelot). Move up the crack to its apex, where it joins a small roof coming in from the right. Decent gear in the roof (yellow and green Aliens helpful). Head up and right to gain a bolt. Pass the bolt, making a heady mantle on the knob above (crux). Continue up easier climbing to gain a crack coming in from the right (decent large pro) and eventually to a 2-ring anchor. Lower off (70')

NOTE: the single bolt was added later with consent of the FA'ist. Initially, this route was rated 5.9 R/X.
content.location: 25' right of 'The Minnow', just past a large pine. Locate a fist sized crack.
